[h1]Arrays[/h1]

An [b]array [/b]is used to store a collection of data, but it may be useful to think of an array as a collection of variables that are all of the [b]same type[/b].
Instead of declaring multiple variables and storing individual values, you can declare a single array to store all the values.
When declaring an array, specify its element types, as well as the number of elements it will hold.  
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="cpp"][b]int [/b]a[5];[/code]
In the example above, variable [b]a[/b] was declared as an array of five integer values [specified in square brackets].
You can initialize the array by specifying the values it holds: [code format="cpp"]int b[5] = {11, 45, 62, 70, 88};[/code]
The values are provided in a [b]comma [/b]separated list, enclosed in [b]{curly braces}[/b].
[note]The number of values between braces { } must not exceed the number of the elements declared within the square brackets [ ].[/note]

quizzes.question: The array in C++ starts counting from:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Accessing Array Elements[/h1]

Index numbers may also be used to assign a new value to an element.[code format="cpp"]int b[] = {11, 45, 62, 70, 88};
b[2] = 42;[/code]
This assigns a value of 42 to the array's third element.
[note]Always remember that the list of elements always begins with the index of 0.[/note]
